We are ordinary people, and all have weaknesses and strengths--no matter who we are. Sometimes the weaknesses seem to outweigh  the   _  and sometimes it's the other way around.  	Many people leave it and   _  it as just bad luck--but not everyone. Some people  _  huge limitations still manage to achieve excellent things. They rise above their weaknesses and do not allow them to  _  their possibilities. 
 	I 47 _ a school prize-giving ceremony not so long ago and the guest speaker was Bill Becroft, who had a severe stutter  as a child.  Instead of   _  this to limit him, he chose to work hard to   _  it. He is now the Principal Youth Judge for New Zealand. Not only did he become  _  , but he did so in a profession where he had to speak in front of others  _  --where his weakness is easy for all to see. If he had not worked on his  _  ability, it would have been very limiting to his life and career prospects.
 	Lots of people face far more significant   _  than you do. They may be missing limbs or are   _  into extreme poverty. But no matter what the limitation, you will   _  find people who have overcome it.
 	At 19 months old, Helen Keller became   _  and lost her sight and hearing before she'd learned to speak. She went   _  to become a world famous author and   _  , and an advocate of many social causes. 
 	Mark Inglis lost both of his legs below the knees in a mountain-climbing   _  , but has since climbed Mt. Everest. No one would have predicted these  _  .
